newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RBA says rates trend reversal would be surprising.
newsitem.headline: RBA says rates trend reversal would be surprising.

text.p: Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) Governor Ian Macfarlane said on Thursday he would be disappointed or surprised if there was a reversal in the trend in short-term interest rates in the immediate term.

"It would be disappoiting or surprising if a reversal were to occur in the immediate term," Macfarlane told a federal government committee in answer to a question about how long interest rates were likely to stay down.
Macfarlane said the bank's policy on interest rates was traditionally "pre-emptive" and that cuts were normally followed by a period of stability.

"We have tended in Australia to make our movements in monetary policy, I think, quite early -- the word there is pre-emptive -- to do two or three quickly then to have it followed a period of stability," Macfarlane said.

"If you look at the experience of the last five or six years I think you would see that is the sort of pattern that has emerged and we hope that is the sort of pattern that could emerge on this occassion," he said.
Macfarlane said he hoped economic conditions do not force the bank to reverse its position on rates.
"I would hope that that would not prove necessary."
